goal.en: This course introduces students to the rise of the English novel, which is roughly coeval with the rise of the British colonial empire, industrial capitalism, and the middle class. We will examine a wide variety of novels (and some film adaptations), analyzing how their narrative form enables the construction of stories that reflect on and reinforce the development of middle-class values. In other words, we will consider how novels shape ostensibly progressive notions such as romantic individualism and female autonomy, as well as how they collude with repressive (sexual) mores, capitalist ideologies, and empire-building. Adopting a roughly chronological order, we will go over the Romantic, Victorian, and Modernist periods. Special emphasis will be placed on the way aesthetic forms are treated as means to carry out ethical practices that are not necessarily fully intentional. By closely engaging with the ambivalence or conflicts surrounding these aesthetic/ethical projects, students are expected to develop a more critical and historical understanding of the rise of English literary culture on the global stage and how it has shaped what are now understood to be Western values.

content.en:
The class will consist of lectures and group discussions followed by groups reporting back to the class. There will be unannounced quizzes. Students are expected to complete assigned readings before each class meeting.
Novels are long, and we will only be able to read excerpts in this survey course, not the full novels. Surveys are meant to familiarize students with a field as a whole rather than looking closely at a few texts.
If time allows over the break, students are encouraged to read some of the novels in full (Chinese translation is fine) before class begins.
In class, all our readings will be in English. Novels we cover are likely to include Robinson Crusoe, Pride and Prejudice, Frankenstein (1818 version), Jane Eyre, Great Expectations, Heart of Darkness, Things Fall Apart, Wide Sargasso Sea, Lord of the Rings (novel excerpt and film trilogy), and The Remains of the Day (novel excerpt and film). However, the reading list is tentative, and I may still make some changes, so please bear that in mind!
